Award.AwardTitle: Molecular Basis of Social Decision Making: Towards a Mechanistic View of Mate Choice
Award.AbstractNarration: How do females choose a mate? Female mate selection promotes population divergence and biodiversity, yet our understanding of how reproductive physiology affects mate selection and ultimately biodiversity is very limited. In this project, cichlid fishes from the East African Great Lakes will be used to unravel the behavioral, physiological and molecular underpinnings of the female reproductive cycle. Cichlids provide a unique opportunity to integrate the molecular and neural basis of female sexuality with the function of mate choice. The research will focus on the cichlid species Astatotilapia burtoni, which has become a major model system to study the physiological, molecular and genomic basis of social behavior, as well as the genus Xenotilapia, which exhibits an extraordinary diversity of mating systems in very closely related species. The three aims will (i) analyze the association of female sexual behavior with hormonal, morphological, and transcriptional changes throughout the reproductive cycle; (ii) test which transcriptional events in the forebrain are associated with mate choice decisions; and (iii) determine the effects of reproductive hormones on mate choice. By combining and integrating multiple levels of investigation and exploiting the spectacular biodiversity of cichlid fishes this project provides an exceptional opportunity to explain mate choice in pharmacological, neuroanatomical, physiological, molecular and genomic terms. This project will provide outstanding educational benefits to urban high school students, undergraduate, graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, including members of underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Charles Darwin was the first to recognize that female mate choice has tremendous potential to drive male character evolution and promote population divergence, yet the process by which females choose a mate still remains a fundamental problem in biology. Female sexuality and reproductive physiology have been studied extensively in a wide range of species, including humans. The brain areas and neuroendocrine pathways involved in receptive and proceptive behaviors have been described in detail, although this growing understanding of the physiological, neural and genetic underpinnings of female sexual behavior comes largely from highly inbred traditional model systems, limiting their utility as models for mate choice and sexual selection. At the same time, non-traditional model systems have provided important insights into the evolutionary processes underlying the recognition and choice of mates. However, the two research fields overlap very little and thus our understanding of how female reproductive physiology regulates the selection of a mate is very limited, even though understanding how endocrine, neural and molecular changes throughout the reproductive cycle influence (and are influenced by) social decisions such as mate choice is a fundamental problem in biology.

 

The cichlid fishes of Africa's Great Lakes provide a unique opportunity to integrate the molecular and neural basis of female sexual behavior with the function of mate choice. The parallel radiations of cichlid species within these lakes have coincided with an extraordinary diversification of male secondary sexual characteristics. The importance of male color pattern for female mate recognition is well documented. Female cichlids recognize conspecific males when visual cues alone are available. Anthropogenic changes in the photic environment reduce conspecific discrimination resulting in a loss of species cohesion. While a great deal of work has focused on the perceptual mechanisms by which female cichlids receive and perceive male signals, little work has been done to understand the hormonal and neuronal modulation of reproductive behavior as it relates to mate choice.

 

Over the life of this award, we succeeded in experimentally uncoupling the mate choice decision from mating itself. Our results show that female A. burtoni a) will spawn without a male present, and b) can be pharmacologically induced to choose a mate even when not gravid. This has allowed us to uncouple gene networks involved with the regulation of the reproductive event from those that regulate the act of mate choice.

 

Also, we used the monophyletic Xenotilapia clade of cichlids, which - as our recent research has shown - has undergone several independent transitions from polygamy to monogamy over the last 1-2 million years. We have used gene expression profiling in the brain to identify gene sets associated with monogamous and polygamous mating behavior in both females and males of four Xenotilapia species, representing two independent evolutionary transitions from polygamy to monogamy. This large transcriptome study allowed us to discover several gene modules associated with monogamy in both evolutionary transitions, suggesting conserved molecular substrates in the face of independent phenotypic evolution.

 

Finally, we reconstructed the evolution of a social decision-making (SDM) network in the vertebrate brain, a set of interconnected and functionally integrated fore- and midbrain nuclei involved in the processing and evaluation of socially salient signals. This work demonstrated that the neural substrates governing complex social decisions are remarkably conserved across vertebrates, including gene expression profiles of neuroendocrine and neuromodulatory pathways.
